title: Protocol for bulk RNA sequencing of enriched human neutrophils from whole blood and estimation of sample purity
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Red blood cell lysis
Timing: 10 min
      A large proportion of whole blood is red blood cells (RBCs), thus the
      first step in isolating neutrophils is an RBC lysis (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
    
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2496-Fig2.jpg
          Figure 2. Schematic overview of the general steps involved in the
          enrichment of neutrophils from fresh whole blood samples
        
        To begin, if the anticoagulant in the vacutainer is not EDTA, add 1 μL
        of 0.5 M EDTA to the whole blood.
      
        Prepare the following solutions (see “materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]”):
        
1× PBS+EDTA.
TCL+2-mercaptoethanol lysis buffer.
        For each individual sample, gently open the vacutainer tube and move
        500 μL of whole blood to a 15 mL conical tube.
      
        Add 8 mL of ACK lysis buffer to each tube using a 10 mL serological
        pipet, pipetting up and down 5 times to mix the sample and lyse the
        RBCs.
      
        Centrifuge the samples at 300 × g for 5 min at 25°C with max
        acceleration and max deceleration.
      
        Aspirate the supernatant, being careful not to disturb the pellet.
        
The pellet contains the neutrophils and all other PMBCs.
        Resuspend the pellet of cells in 250 μL of 25°C 1× PBS+EDTA by pipetting
        up and down gently 5 times.
      
Neutrophil enrichment
Timing: 40–60 min
    
      Once most RBCs have been removed and the pellet is resuspended, enrichment
      for neutrophils via EasySep isolation can be performed (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
    
Vortex EasySep™ RapidSpheres™ for 30 s.
Add 50 μL of EasySep™ Isolation Cocktail to each sample.
Add 50 μL of RapidSpheres to each sample.
Mix gently by pipetting up and down 10 times.
Incubate samples for 5 min at 25°C.
Top up the volume of each tube to 4 mL with 1× PBS+EDTA.
Cap all of the 15 mL conical tubes tightly.

Mix gently by tilting the samples back and forth 5 times.
Remove the lid from each 15 mL conical tube.
        Place samples in the EasyEights™ EasySep™ Magnet, ensuring that all
        tubes sit all the way down.
      
Incubate samples on the magnet for 5 min at 25°C.
        Use a 5 mL serological pipet to transfer the supernatant of the samples
        into a new set of labeled 15 mL conical tubes.
        
Discard tubes containing the RapidSpheres.
Note: Angle the pipet such that the tip is
      opposite the magnet to avoid touching the magnetic beads. The procedure is
      a negative selection, meaning that neutrophils remain in the supernatant
      while PBMCs are captured by the RapidSpheres.
    
        Add 25 μL of RapidSpheres to the tubes containing the supernatant from
        the first selection step.
      
        Cap samples tightly and mix gently by tilting the samples back and forth
        5 times.
      
Incubate samples for 5 min at 25°C.
        Following the incubation, place tubes on the EasySep magnet and incubate
        for 5 min.
      
        Use a 5 mL serological pipet to transfer the supernatant of the samples
        into a new set of labeled 15 mL conical tubes.
        
Discard tubes containing the RapidSpheres pellet.
        Place the samples (supernatant) back on the EasySep magnet and incubate
        for 5 min.
      
Note: This additional incubation on the
      magnet is necessary in order to pull any remaining RapidSpheres from the
      suspension.
    
        Use a 5 mL serological pipet to carefully transfer 3.5 mL of the
        supernatant of the samples into a new set of labeled 15 mL conical
        tubes.
        
Discard tubes containing the RapidSpheres pellet.
        Cap all samples and centrifuge at 300 × g for 5 min at 25°C.
      
        Aspirate the supernatant, being careful not to disturb the pellet.
      
Note: The cell pellet should now be highly
      enriched for neutrophils with minimal other cell species present.

Resuspend the isolated neutrophils in 1 mL 1× PBS + EDTA.
Mix thoroughly by pipetting up and down.
Cell counting and lysis
Timing: 5–20 min
      Once isolated, neutrophils should be counted in order to determine the
      yield and to determine the correct volume of lysis buffer to use so that
      all samples are at the same concentration for bulk RNA sequencing library
      preparation.
    
        Mix 10 μL of neutrophil suspension with 10 μL of trypan blue by
        pipetting.
      
Add 10 μL to a counting chamber of a hemocytometer.
        Using a hemocytometer or an automated cell counter, determine the total
        number of neutrophils isolated from each sample.
      
Note: if an automated cell counter is
      used, be sure to adjust the detection gates to count only the smaller
      population of cells. Larger leukocytes may still be present at low levels
      in the sample, and the goal is to determine the neutrophil count, not the
      absolute cell count of each sample.
    
        Move 2 × 105 cells to a 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube by transferring
        an appropriate volume of the cell suspension based on the determined
        count/concentration.
      
        Top up the tube of cells to 1.5 mL total volume by adding additional 1×
        PBS+EDTA.
      
Centrifuge at 300 × g for 5 min at 25°C.
        Aspirate the supernatant, being careful not to disturb the pellet.
        
Remove the last bit of supernatant with a 20–200 μL pipette.
        Resuspend the neutrophils in 200 μL of the prepared TCL + 1%
        2-mercaptoethanol lysis buffer.
        
            If a lower number of cells than desired were retrieved, resuspend
            the cells in a lower volume such that the final lysis concentration
            is 1,000 cells/μL.
          
Mix well to fully lyse all cells.
        Transfer 100 μL per tube to two labeled cryopreservation tubes.
        
Place tubes on dry ice immediately.

After 5 min, the aliquoted lysates can be moved to storage at −80°C.
      
Optional: If enough of the original
      sample remains, it may be helpful to check for successful enrichment by
      flow cytometry, comparing the unenriched whole blood to the enriched
      neutrophil product. A suggested antibody panel for discriminating between
      the various PBMCs and neutrophils is suggested in LaSalle et al.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]
      and includes CD3, CD14, CD16, CD19, CD20, CD56, CD66b.
    
Modified Smart-Seq2 cDNA generation
Timing: 6–8 h
      Once neutrophils have been enriched, cDNA can now be prepared via a
      modified version of the Smart-Seq2 protocol11[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib11] and
      then used for downstream library preparation. These steps involve
      purifying RNA from the lysed cells, reverse transcription of mRNA
      transcripts to cDNA, whole-transcriptome amplification, and purification
      of amplified cDNA.
    
        Prepare neutrophil samples for cDNA generation.
        
Bring RNA-SPRI beads to 25°C.
Thaw lysed neutrophils on ice.
            Pipette 20 μL (at a concentration of 1,000 cells/μL) of each
            neutrophil lysis sample into the well of a 96-well plate on ice.
          
Centrifuge plates at 1,500 rpm for 30 s at 4°C.
Place plate(s) back on ice.
            Cover with the lid of a pipette tip box, until beginning the
            following step.
          
        Prepare RNA-SPRI beads.
        
Vortex the beads for 30 s.
            Use a serological pipet to transfer the necessary volume (44 μL per
            sample, plus excess) into a reagent reservoir.
          
        Using a multichannel pipette, add 44 μL of RNA-SPRI beads (2.2 times the
        sample volume) to samples.
      
Mix thoroughly by pipetting up and down.
        Cover the plate(s), then incubate for 10 min at 25°C.
        
            During this incubation, prepare 50 mL of 80% EtOH: 40 mL EtOH and
            10 mL ddH2O.
          
            Also prepare the appropriate volume of Smart-Seq2 Mix-1 (see
            “materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]”),
            plus excess (10%), and set aside on ice.

Following the incubation, place the plate on the DynaMag™-96 Side
        Skirted Magnet and incubate for 5 min at 25°C.
      
        Remove the supernatant.
        
            Aspirate the liquid by angling the tips of the pipette opposite to
            the beads.
          
Critical: Do not disturb the beads.
      RNA from the neutrophils is bound to them, and any loss of beads at this
      step will result in loss of genetic material input for subsequent steps.
    
        Use a serological pipet to fill a reagent reservoir with 80% EtOH.
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2496-Fig3.jpg
              Figure 3. Smart-Seq2 cDNA generation bead washing
            
              (A–C) As the 96-well plate is moved side to side on the
              side-skirted plate magnet as depicted in A–C, note how the pellets
              of beads move from the right side of the well to the left, and
              then back to the right. This movement of the beads through the
              ethanol allows for superior removal of non-nucleic acids and
              better retrieval of RNA.
            
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2496-Fig4.jpg
              Figure 4. Appropriate way to cover SPRI beads during drying
            
              The lid must be slightly skewed in order to increase airflow. If
              the plate is covered too tightly, the beads will dry unevenly and
              take too long, enabling RNA degradation.
            
        Wash the beads in 100 μL of 80% EtOH twice.
        
Add the EtOH, ensuring the beads are covered.
            Agitate the beads, moving the plate side to side on the magnet such
            that the beads move from one side of the well to the other side (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
            
Note: Make sure to move in both
              directions so that samples in columns A and H are washed properly.
            
            Place the plate on the magnet and incubate for 30–60 s to allow all
            beads to come out of solution.
          
Use a P200 pipette to remove the ethanol.
Repeat steps a-d (total 2 washes).

After the final removal of the EtOH with the P200, use a P20 to
            remove any additional EtOH left behind in the wells.
          
        After complete removal of the EtOH, keep the plate on the magnet and
        allow the RNA-SPRI beads to dry for around 10 min, until cracks in the
        beads are visible.
        
            Cover the plate to keep out contaminants but skew the lid to allow
            for more airflow/easier evaporation, as shown in
            Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4].
            
Critical: Once cracks appear,
              proceed to the next step. Overdrying of the RNA-SPRI beads can
              negatively impact sample yields.
            
            Dilute 100 μL of 1 M MgCl2 in 900 μL nuclease-free water
            to make a 100 mM stock solution.
          
            During this incubation, prepare the appropriate volume of
            Smart-Seq2 Mix-2 (see “materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]”), plus excess, without adding Maxima H Minus
            reverse transcriptase.
            
Set aside on ice.
            Start the Denaturing protocol on the thermocycler.
            
                Immediately press pause so that the lid and block get up to
                temperature.
                table:files/protocols_protocol_2496_5.csv
        Elute RNA from the dry RNA-SPRI beads by adding 4 μL of Smart-Seq2 Mix-1
        and resuspending the samples thoroughly.
      
Seal the plate with a foil plate seal.
        Centrifuge plate to get rid of any bubbles.
        
Set the centrifuge to run at 300 × g for 1 min.
            Start the spin but stop it once the speed has risen to 300 × g
            to eliminate bubbles but prevent pelleting of the magnetic beads.
          
        Place the samples in the thermocycler and resume the Denaturing
        protocol.
      
        As soon as the 72°C step completes, immediately place samples on ice.
        
Do not wait for the thermocycler to ramp down to 4°C.
            After placing the samples on ice, start the Reverse Transcription
            (RT) protocol on the thermocycler and immediately press pause to
            allow the block and the lid to come up to temperature.
          
table:files/protocols_protocol_2496_6.csv

Add Maxima H Minus reverse transcriptase to Smart-Seq2 Mix-2, pipette to
        mix.
      
Spin down for 5 s in a benchtop microcentrifuge.
        With the plate of samples on ice, carefully remove the plate seal and
        add 7 μL of Smart-Seq2 Mix-2 to each well.
        
            Mix by pipetting up and down 10 times or until RNA-SPRI beads are
            resuspended.
          
Re-seal the plate with a fresh foil seal.
        Centrifuge plate to get rid of any bubbles.
        
Set the centrifuge to run at 300 × g for 1 min.
            Start the spin but stop it once the speed has risen to 300 × g
            to eliminate bubbles but prevent pelleting of the magnetic beads.
          
        Place the plate in the thermocycler and resume the RT protocol.
        
            15–20 min before the program ends, take the KAPA HiFi HotStart
            ReadyMix and the ISPCR primers out of the freezer to thaw on ice.
          
        When the RT program has ended, remove the samples from the thermocycler
        and place the plate on ice.
        
            After placing the samples on ice, start the PCR Preamplification
            program on the thermocycler and immediately press pause to allow the
            block and the lid to come up to temperature.
            table:files/protocols_protocol_2496_7.csv
            Prepare Smart-Seq2 Mix-3 (see “materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]”) and place on ice.
          
Carefully remove the foil plate seal.
        Add 14 μL of Mix-3 to samples and mix by pipetting up and down 10 times
        or until RNA-SPRI beads are resuspended.
      
Re-seal the plate with a fresh foil seal.
        Centrifuge plate to get rid of any bubbles.
        
Set the centrifuge to run at 300 × g for 1 min.
            Start the spin but stop it once the speed has risen to 300 × g
            to eliminate bubbles but prevent pelleting of the magnetic beads.
          
        Place the samples in the thermocycler and resume the PCR
        Preamplification program.

Pause point: Samples can be held at
      4°C for up to 24 h once the PCR Preamplification is completed.
    
Critical: Before moving to the next
      step, make sure to equilibrate the AMPure XP SPRI beads to 25°C (∼30 min).
    
        Prepare AMPure XP SPRI beads.
        
Vortex the beads for 30 s.
            Use a serological pipet to transfer the necessary volume (40 μL
            total per sample, plus excess) into a reagent reservoir.
          
        Purify PCR products.
        
            Using a multichannel pipette, add 20 μL of AMPure XP SPRI beads (0.8
            times the sample volume) to samples.
          
Mix thoroughly by pipetting up and down.
Cover the plate(s), then incubate for 5 min at 25°C.
        Following the incubation, place the plate on the magnet and incubate for
        5 min at 25°C.
        
            During this incubation, prepare 50 mL of 70% EtOH: 35 mL EtOH and
            15 mL ddH2O.
          
        Remove the supernatant.
        
            Aspirate the liquid by angling the tips of the pipette opposite to
            the beads.
          
        Use a serological pipet to fill a reagent reservoir with 70% EtOH.
      
        Wash the beads in 100 μL of 70% EtOH twice.
        
Add the EtOH, ensuring the beads are covered.
            Agitate the beads, moving the plate side to side on the magnet such
            that the beads move from one side of the well to the other side.
            
Note: Make sure to move in both
              directions so that samples in columns A and H are washed properly.
            
            Place the plate on the magnet and incubate for 30–60 s to allow all
            beads to come out of solution.
          
Use a P200 pipette to remove the ethanol.
Repeat steps a-d.
            After removing the EtOH with the P200, use a P20 to remove any
            additional EtOH left behind in the wells.
          
        After complete removal of the EtOH, keep the plate on the magnet and

allow the AMPure XP SPRI beads to dry for around 10 min, until cracks in
        the beads are visible.
        
            While the beads are drying, use a serological pipet to transfer an
            excess of TE buffer to a reagent reservoir.
          
            Additionally, prepare/label a new 96-well plate which will be used
            for elution.
          
        Elute amplified cDNA from the dry AMPure XP SPRI beads by adding 25 μL
        of TE buffer and resuspending the samples thoroughly.
      
Incubate for 1 min at 25°C.
        Place the plate on the magnet and wait until all magnetic beads have
        come out of solution.
        
In most cases, this will take approximately 1 min.
        With a pipette set to 25 μL, transfer the supernatants (containing the
        cDNA) to the new 96-well plate.
      
        Perform a second round of purification, repeating steps 70–80, for a
        total of 2 cleanup cycles.
      
        Store samples at 4°C for 1–2 days, or at −20°C for longer durations.
      
Pause point: Samples can be held at
      4°C for 1–2 days (or at −20°C for up to 4 weeks, without freeze/thaw)
      following cDNA purification and before moving on to cDNA quality control.
    
cDNA quality control
Timing: 1–2 h
      Prior to taking the cDNA generated via this modified Smart-Seq2 protocol
      forward into library preparation for bulk RNA sequencing, the quality of
      the cDNA must be determined. We use two distinct metrics to do so: a
      measurement of the concentration of each individual sample using a
      plate-based Qubit dsDNA HS assay, and a measurement of the size
      distribution of cDNAs in representative samples via generation of
      BioAnalyzer traces.
    
        Perform a Qubit assay using a Qubit™ dsDNA HS kit.
        
Centrifuge plates of cDNA for 5 s and then place on ice.
            Prepare enough Qubit working solution for all of the samples you

will be testing and for 8 standards (198 μL per sample/standard),
            plus excess.
            
                Dilute the appropriate volume of Qubit™ dsDNA HS Reagent 1:200
                in dsDNA HS Buffer.
              
                Wrap the tube in aluminum foil to protect from light, and set
                aside.
              
            Prepare standards.
            
Prepare an 8-well PCR strip tube and label wells 1–8.
                Add 25 μL of standard-1 (provided with the kit) into all wells
                except the first one.
              
                Add 50 μL of standard-2 to the first empty well, take 25 μL, add
                to the second well containing 25 μL of standard-1 and mix.
              
                Continue with the serial dilution until the 7th well, leaving
                the 8th well with only 25 μL of standard-1.
              
            Obtain one black-sided spectrophotometer assay plate per plate of
            neutrophils cDNA as well as an additional plate for the standards.
            
                The standards should be prepared in triplicate, so 24 wells
                (columns A-C) should be prepped.
              
            Pour the prepared Qubit working solution into a reagent reservoir.
            
                Use a multichannel pipette to add 198 μL of Qubit solution into
                each well that will be used to measure samples/standards.
              
            Place the plate of cDNA on the side-skirted magnet.
            
                Use a multichannel pipet to transfer 2 μL of sample into the
                corresponding wells in the plate containing Qubit working
                reagent.
              
            Transfer 2 μL of standards to the appropriate wells on the standard
            plate.
          
            Seal all plates thoroughly with a plastic plate seal, vortex for
            5–10 s, then spin down.
          
            Remove plate seals and read on a plate-based
            spectrophotometer/fluorometer.
            
Excitation: 485 nm; emission: 530 nm.
            Use the standards to create a standard curve and linear formula to
            relate fluorescence to dsDNA concentration.
            
                Use this formula to determine the concentration of each sample.
              
        Once neutrophil cDNA concentrations have been determined, select 11
        samples from each plate to run on an Agilent Bioanalyzer using the

High-Sensitivity DNA Bioanalyzer Kit.
        
            Choose the samples such that you will be able to observe the DNA
            quality over the range of concentrations measured via the Qubit
            assay.
          
            Prepare the Bioanalyzer chip and load the 11 samples according to
            the
            manufacturer’s protocol[href=https://www.agilent.com/cs/library/usermanuals/public/G2938-90322_HighSensitivityDNAKit_QSG.pdf].
          
            Example traces are shown below in Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5].
            
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2496-Fig5.jpg
                  Figure 5. Example Bioanalyzer traces from two different bulk
                  neutrophil cDNA samples following preparation via SmartSeq2
                  and clean-ups
                
                  Note the size distributions and peaks of both traces. The
                  upper represents an ideal cDNA trace, with all fragments
                  larger than 500 bp. The lower trace is still acceptable to
                  take forward into library preparation, but the presence of
                  cDNA fragments lower than 500 bp suggests that some mRNA
                  degradation occurred prior to the reverse transcription
                  reaction.
                
Pause point: Samples can be held at
      4°C overnight or at −20°C for up to 4 weeks (without freeze/thaw)
      following cDNA purification and before moving on to library preparation.
    
Modified Nextera library generation
Timing: 2–3 h
      Illumina’s Nextera XT Library Prep Kit is a fast and easy to use library
      preparation method. We have modified and optimized the protocol to work
      with ultra-low DNA inputs of 0.1–0.2 ng in a 384-well plate format to
      allow for easy multiplexing. This is ideal for use with cell-types such as
      neutrophils that have relatively small transcriptomes and enables a
      low-effort way to process many samples for RNAseq library generation at
      one time.
    
        Following library preparation, all samples should be diluted to
        0.1–0.2 ng/μL.
        
Note: We have found that the easiest
          way to do this is to create a 96-well “dilution plate” that
          corresponds to each plate of cDNA generated via SmartSeq2.
        
            First, 10 μL of each sample determined to already have
            concentrations in the range of 0.1–0.2 ng/μL should be transferred

to the corresponding sample wells in the dilution plate.
            
                10 μL of any samples below the desired concentration should also
                be transferred at this time.
              
            All remaining samples should be diluted using ultra-pure,
            double-distilled water.
          
            At least 1 μL of original cDNA should be used to create the diluted
            sample, and the total dilution volume should be no less than 10 μL.
          
        Prepare the set-up for library generation.
        
            Obtain two large ice buckets, and place a metal 384-well plate
            cooling block on one of them.
          
            Retrieve Tagmentation DNA Buffer (TD) and Amplicon Tagment Mix (ATM)
            from storage at −20°C and allow to thaw on ice.
          
            Retrieve the prepared index plates (Q1, Q2, Q3, Q4) and thaw at 25°C
            before placing on ice.
          
            If diluted plates were held at 4°C, place on ice.
            
                If they were stored at −20°C, allow them to thaw at 25°C and
                then place on ice.
              
            Retrieve a fresh 384-well PCR plate for the library generation.
          
Obtain a 96-well plate for use as a reagent plate.
        Add TD, ATM, and diluted samples to the 384-well PCR plate.
        
            Aliquot 55 μL of TD into all 12 wells of row A of the reagent plate.
          
            Use two tip boxes (one row of tips per row of the 384-well plate) to
            transfer 1.25 μL of TD into each well of the 384-well plate.
          
            Aliquot 30 μL of ATM into all 12 wells of row B of the reagent
            plate.
          
            Use four tip boxes (two rows of tips per row of the 384-well plate)
            to transfer 0.625 μL of ATM to each well of the 384-well plate.
          
            Use four tip boxes to transfer 0.625 μL of diluted samples into the
            384-well plate, keeping track of the positions of samples in order

to match them with the unique indices that will be added in step 93.
            
                Seal the 384-well plate with a foil plate seal and mix samples
                by tapping gently on the benchtop.
              
            Spin the plate at 20,000 × g for 3 min to ensure that there
            are no bubbles.
          
Critical: Make sure that the library
      plate is held on ice while samples are added, and place the plate
      immediately back on ice after centrifugation. This will limit premature
      tagmentation of the cDNA.
    
        Perform the tagmentation reaction.
        
            Put the plate in a thermocycler equipped with a 384-well plate
            block, and run the Make NTA protocol.
          
table:files/protocols_protocol_2496_8.csv
        While the tagmentation reaction is occurring, prepare for the next
        steps.
        
            Retrieve the NT buffer (NT) from storage at 25°C, and aliquot 30 μL
            of TD into all 12 wells of row C of the reagent plate.
          
Replace the TD and ATM at −20°C.
Reseal the cDNA plates and store at −20°C.
        As soon as the 55°C step of the Make NTA program finishes and the
        thermocycler begins to ramp down to 10°C, take the plate out and
        immediately place it on ice.
      
        Carefully remove the foil plate seal and add NT to the tagmented
        samples.
        
            Use four tip boxes to transfer 0.625 μL of NT to each well of the
            384-well plate.
          
            Seal the plate and mix samples by tapping gently on the benchtop.
          
            Spin the plate at 20,000 × g for 3 min to ensure that there
            are no bubbles.
          
            Incubate the plate for 10 min at 25°C.
            
                Begin the timer for this incubation as soon as you take the
                plate out of the centrifuge.
              
Critical: Place the library plate back
      on the metal block on ice as soon as possible after the tagmentation

reaction (55°C step) is complete and add the NT carefully but efficiently
      to prevent over-tagmentation of the cDNA.
    
        While the samples are incubating with NT, prepare for the next steps.
        
            Retrieve the NPM reagent from storage at −20°C and place on ice.
          
Ensure that the index plates have thawed.
            Gently vortex the index plates and then spin them down by allowing
            the centrifuge to reach 20,000 × g before stopping it.
          
        Remove the foil plate seal, then add NPM and indices.
        
            Aliquot 80 μL of NPM into all 12 wells of row D of the reagent
            plate.
          
            Use four tip boxes to transfer 1.875 μL of NPM into each well of the
            384-well plate.
          
            Use four tip boxes to add 1.25 μL of indices to each well of the
            384-well plate. Q1 indices will be added to rows 1–4 of the 384-well
            plate, Q2 to rows 5–8, etc.
            
                This layout is visualized in
                Table S1[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2496-Mmc1.xlsx]
                (sheet “i5_i7_index_and_layout”).
              
            Seal the plate and mix the samples by tapping gently on the
            benchtop.
          
Spin the plate at 20,000 × g for 3 min.
            Put the plate in a thermocycler equipped with a 384-well plate
            block, and run the Nextera PCR protocol.
          
table:files/protocols_protocol_2496_9.csv
        Pool the individual samples.
        
            Once the Nextera PCR program has finished and the thermocycler is
            holding at 4°C, remove the place and spin it at 20,000 × g
            for 3 min.
          
            Using the four boxes of low-retention tips, pool together 2.5 μL of
            each sample from the 384-well plate into row H of the reagent plate.
          
Seal the plate with a foil seal.
            Spin the plate at 20,000 × g for 1 min to eliminate any
            bubbles.
          
            Form the final pooled library by collecting all of the contents of
            row H into a 2 mL DNA LoBind Eppendorf tube.

Set the pipette to 80 μL to ensure that you are collecting all
                of the liquid from each well of row H.
              
        Perform the first purification of the cDNA library.
        
            Ensure that the AMPure XP SPRI beads are at 25°C and vortex them for
            30 s to resuspend.
          
Prepare fresh 80% EtOH.
            Add 0.9 volumes of AMPure XP SPRI beads to the sample (for a library
            generated from 384 samples the final volume will be 960 μL so 864 μL
            of beads would be added, for example).
          
Mix well by pipetting up and down.
            Incubate bead/library mixture at 25°C for 5 min.
            
Note: This mixture will be
              viscous. Ensure that the total volume of the mixture is dispensed
              by pipetting slowly.
            
            Incubate the sample on a DynaMag™-2 Magnet for 5 min.
            
                At the end of the 5 min, tighten the cluster of beads using the
                96-well plate magnet.
              
            Remove the supernatant, being careful not to disturb the beads.
          
            Wash the beads twice with 1 mL of 80% EtOH, making sure that the
            beads are covered.
          
            For each wash, rotate the Eppendorf tube at least twice on the
            magnet.
            
Note: Due to the size of the
              pellet, not all of the beads will move when the tube is turned.
              This is okay.
            
            After the second wash, remove all of the EtOH. Ensure that all EtOH
            is removed by aspirating any final drops left in the tube with a
            20 μL tip.
          
            Dry the beads for 10 min, or until cracks start to appear in the
            cluster. During the drying period, cover the tube loosely with the
            lid of a pipette tip box.
          
            Elute the library in 200 μL of TE buffer, remove the sample from the
            magnet, and pipette up and down to resuspend. Incubate for 5 min at
            25°C.

Critical: make sure that the
              magnetic beads are wet before removing the Eppendorf tube from the
              magnet. Not doing so can result in a loss of sample.
            
Place the sample on the magnet for 5 min.
            Remove the supernatant (contains the cDNA library) to a new 1.5 mL
            DNA LoBind Eppendorf tube.
            
                Discard the 2 mL tube containing the bead pellet.
                
Note: It is okay if a small
                  amount of beads are transferred with the sample.
                
        Perform the second purification of the cDNA library.
        
            Add 180 μL (0.9 times the sample volume) of AMPure XP SPRI beads to
            the sample. Mix well by pipetting up and down, and then incubate at
            25°C for 5 min.
          
            Incubate the sample on the tube magnet for 5 min. At the end of the
            5 min, tighten the cluster of beads using the 96-well plate magnet.
          
            Remove the supernatant, being careful not to disturb the beads.
          
            Wash the beads twice with 1 mL of 80% EtOH, making sure that the
            beads are covered.
            
                For each wash, rotate the Eppendorf tube at least twice on the
                magnet.
              
            After the second wash, remove all of the EtOH.
            
                Ensure that all EtOH is removed by aspirating any final drops
                left in the tube with a 20 μL tip.
              
            Dry the beads for 10 min, or until cracks start to appear in the
            cluster.
            
                During the drying period, cover the tube loosely with the lid of
                a pipette tip box.
              
            Elute the library in 200 μL of TE buffer, remove the sample from the
            magnet, and pipette up and down to resuspend.
          
Incubate for 5 min at 25°C.
Place the sample on the magnet for 5 min.
            Remove the supernatant (contains the purified library) to a new
            1.5 mL DNA LoBind Eppendorf tube.

            Dilute the library 1:10 in water, and analyze the size distribution

            Determine the concentration of the library using a
            QubitTM dsDNA HS kit[href=https://www.thermofisher.com/document-connect/document-connect.html?url=https://assets.thermofisher.com/TFS-Assets%2FLSG%2Fmanuals%2FQubit_dsDNA_HS_Assay_UG.pdf].
            
                Prepare 700 μL of Qubit working solution by diluting the

                Buffer.
              
                For the cDNA library, combine 199 μL of Qubit working solution

Critical: Hold the tube
                  containing the cDNA library on the tube magnet while
                  transferring the sample. Any bead contamination will mess up
                  the results of the Qubit assay.
                
                Prepare standards 1 and 2 by combining 190 μL of Qubit working

                fluorometer.

                concentration of the cDNA library.
                
Pause point: the

            For the NovaSeq S4, use the following read parameters for 300 total

      The alignment and quantification methods used herein are based on the

GTEx/TOPMed RNA-seq pipeline from the Broad Institute, with custom
      modifications.
    
Obtain paired-end FASTQ files from the sequencer.
Note: Each sample should have one R1 and

      used, it may be necessary to concatenate files from multiple lanes of a

Quality control analysis
Timing: 2 h–2 days
    
        Import the count matrix, transcripts-per-million (TPM) matrix, quality
        control metrics, and other metadata into R.
      
        Log transform the TPM data and run a principal component analysis (PCA)
        (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]).
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2496-Fig7.jpg
              Figure 7. Principal component analysis (PCA) plots displaying
              Exonic Rate and Median 3′ bias of samples pre- and post-quality
              control filtration
            
            Plot the various quality control metrics over the PCA to see if any
            parameters are driving outlier behavior and which should be filtered
            on.
          
>genepc <-
          read.delim(paste0(prefix,"Ensembl_to_Symbol.txt"))
>logTPM <- log2(TPM + 1)
>proteincoding <- genepc$Gene.stable.ID[genepc$Gene.type ==
          "protein_coding"]
>logPCG <- logTPM[which(rownames(logTPM) %in%
          proteincoding),]
>logPCG <- logPCG[which(rowSums(logPCG) > 0),]
>pcaResults <- prcomp(t(logPCG), center = T, scale. = T)
        Filter out low quality samples.

The exact parameters for filtration will depend on the source and
            inherent quality of the dataset.
          
            For this neutrophil dataset, the criteria we find to retain the most
            high-quality samples is:
            
Percent of mitochondrial reads < 20%
Genes Detected > 10,000.
Median Exon CV < 1.
Exon CV MAD < 0.75.
Exonic rate > 25%.
Median 3′ bias < 0.9.
                Other quality control metrics may be considered depending on the
                context; for example, one could generate a “housekeeping gene”
                score based on genes that viable cells should express and remove
                samples below a threshold.
              
        Run the PCA once more, this time using only the high-quality samples (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]). Check that technical bias does not have a major impact on the data
        distribution.
      
        Check that the sample filtration procedure has not introduced bias into
        the dataset.
        
            For example, it is possible that samples from patients with severe
            disease could have lower quality and be systematically filtered,
            biasing the data towards patients with mild disease.
          
            Similar bias could unintentionally be introduced on the basis of
            age, gender, race, ethnicity, disease status, or comorbidities.
          
            To test whether there is an association between sample exclusion and
            one of these variables, perform a Fisher test on the two-way table
            comparing inclusion status versus the categories of the clinical
            variable.

percentages for each sample

            Check for associations between the various estimates and the

Note: For example, we identified an
      association between higher estimated T/NK cell fraction and non-severe
      COVID-19, which could potentially confound the results of a differential
